I love the theme. What a shame this just seems a tad outdated. Better wargames out there.

The "duck, duck, goose!" combat resolution is the fatal flaw in anotherwise amazing design. And given the number of editions, it clearly demonstrates the continue popularity of the game: but something has to change before I play it again.

So, why offer it for trade? The Berg GMT games (a series that he did not finish, but hopefully someone will) are a pain with all the combat modifiers; but it seems a strong and authentic way to portray the combat.

I appreciate the legacy left by this game, as I can see that this must have been a huge revolution in war games. I particularly like the use of the battle cards. I'm not necessarily opposed to dice to resolve combat, but the use of cards, even if it is kind of Old Maid-ish, was refreshing and surprisingly fun.

Though I can tell that I will never become an expert in the game, I was grateful to be taught the game and would willingly play it again.

7/19/17 - I've had to come to terms with the fact that I just don't like this game very much. I recognize that it's good, so I have to chalk this up to my own personal tastes and sense of aesthetics. History aside, I don't like how the game takes place around the periphery of the board, with just gobs of empty, unplayable sea in the middle. Also, I feel like there is so little the players can count on--no refuge of any kind from the constant high stakes and tension. I don't know; it just doesn't work for me. In spite of its obvious inferiority of design, I much prefer We the People/Washington's War. [Edit: Caesar: Rome vs Gaul trumps Washington's War and IMO is easily the best of the three).

I suspect this will soon be a 10. Like Cosmic Encounter, a piece of alien technology that was ahead of its time in a bygone era. This influenced so many afterward. The cardplay isn't as intricate as in other CDGs (i.e. no need to disaster-manage mandatory events), but it more than makes up for it with dynamic boardplay and possibilities for wild maneuvers. Cut your opponents' supply/LOC off, and compete for majorities in provinces to get combat bonuses and zero-sum points. Combat is its own minigame and still original, and is welcome in a 2-player game (almost like those turn-based strategy games where we leave the global map and enter a tactical battlefield).

The only potential misgiving I have is the rich-get-richer snowball that severely punishes early missteps and gives the early loser no help at turning the tide besides just hoping for a better card draw. I'm not asking for a bludgeon to help the loser, like in Antike Duellum, but I like subtle ways of implementing a rubber band effect e.g. maybe the smaller my controlled area, the easier it is to manage and counter-attack. Wait-and-see on whether this holds it back from a 10.

One of the best 2p CDG's ever invented. Very balanced and possesses a variety of strategies available to each side to win. Truly a classic. This is one of the finest board game designs ever made. Along with "We the People" (the 1st CDG, the game that invented the genre), these two CDG board games define the highest bar of game design quality in the CDG genre.

El primer CDG propiamente dicho, que cogió el innovador diseño de We The People y lo elevó en profundidad sin complicar demasiado las reglas. El hecho de que todas las cartas tengan puntos de operaciones y eventos crea ese dilema tan característico de este sistema, y apareció por primera vez aquí, de forma elegante. El juego es asimétrico pero al mismo tiempo equilibrado, reproduciendo las opciones y los dilemas estratégicos que tuvieron ambos bandos en la historia representada. El combate con cartas de batalla es un juego en sí mismo, aunque pueda alargar en exceso la partida.
